question: What is a 'cultivating raiyat' according to the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: A 'cultivating raiyat' is a raiyat or an under-raiyat who holds land by cultivating it either by himself or by members of his family or by servants or by bargadars or by or with the aid of hired labourers or with the aid of partners.
context: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant to the subject or context, (9) 'cultivating raiyat' or 'cultivating under-raiyat' means a raiyat or an under-raiyat, as the case may be, who holds land by cultivating it either by himself or by members of his family or by servants or by bargadars or by or with the aid of hired labourers or with the aid of partners.

question: What does 'derelict tea garden' refer to in the context of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: A 'derelict tea garden' refers to a parcel or group of parcels of land held under single management which was held, settled or leased for the purpose of cultivation or manufacture of tea, or which has contained or contains tea bushes, and which has been notified by the Government to be a derelict tea garden and includes all buildings on such land.
context: Provided that in notifying a parcel or parcels of land as a derelict tea garden, the Government may have regard to- (i) whether such land is planted to the extent of less than 15 per cent of its area with tea of which no substantial proportion has been planted in the previous 5 years; and (ii) the opinion of the Tea Board as to whether the area planted with tea more than 7 years previously has produced per acre in the last 3 years less than 25 per cent of the average production per acre of the whole area planted with tea in the Province for that period.

question: What does 'encumbrance' mean in relation to an estate, tenure, holding, tenancy or land under this Act?
answer: Encumbrance means any mortgage, charge, lien, sub-tenancy, easement or other right or interest created by the holder thereof on such estate, tenure, holding, tenancy or land or in limitation of his own interest therein.
context: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant to the subject or context, (10) 'encumbrance', in relation to any estate, tenure, holding, tenancy or land, means any mortgage, charge, lien, sub-tenancy, easement or other right or interest created by the holder thereof on such estate, tenure, holding, tenancy or land or in limitation of his own interest therein.

question: What is a 'registered' document in the context of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: A 'registered' document is one registered under any Act for the time being in force for the registration of documents.
context: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant to the subject or context, (11) 'registered', in relation to any document, means registered under any Act for the registration of documents.

question: What is a 'proprietor' in the context of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950?
answer: A 'proprietor' means a person owning, whether in trust or for his own benefit, an estate or a part of an estate.
context: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant to the subject or context, (20) 'proprietor', in relation to a person, means a person owning, whether in trust or for his own benefit, an estate or a part of an estate.

question: What is the right of pre-emption under section 96?
answer: The right of pre-emption under section 96 allows a portion or share of a holding of a raiyat to be sold to a co-sharer tenant in the holding by inheritance or to a person to whom sale can be made under section 90.
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

question: When can an application under sub-section (1) be dismissed?
answer: An application under sub-section (1) shall be dismissed unless the applicant or applicants, at the time of making it, deposit in the Court the amount of the consideration money of the sold holding or portion or share as stated in the notice under section 89 or in the deed of sale, as the case may be, and an amount calculated at the rate of twenty five per centum of the amount referred to in clause (a), and an amount calculated at the rate of eight per centum simple annual interest upon the amount referred to in clause (a) for the period from the date of the execution of the deed of sale to the date of filing of the application for preemption.
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

question: How much compensation is required for the application under section 96?
answer: The amount calculated at the rate of twenty five per centum of the amount referred to in clause (a) for the period from the date of the execution of the deed of sale to the date of filing of the application for preemption.
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

question: Who can apply to the Court for the sale of a portion of a raiyat?
answer: Co-sharer tenants by inheritance or a person to whom sale can be made under section 90.
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

question: When does the Court have the right to apportion the holding or portion?
answer: The Court shall apportion the holding or the portion or share among the applicants or applicants who have joined in the original application under sub-section (6) within such period as it may fix.
context: The State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

question: What is the purpose of Section 2A?
answer: The purpose of Section 2A is to allow the government in public interest to exempt the interests of any local authority in any land or class of lands from acquisition under the provision of this Act.
